author: By William J. Broad
title: Math That Helped Solve Fermat’s Theorem Now Safeguards the Digital World
description: The mathematicians who toiled on the famous enigma also devised powerful forms of end-to-end encryption.
content: Defenses against digital snoopers keep getting stronger. Encryption is what keeps communications safe when you use Signal and other messaging apps, make online financial transactions, buy and sell cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and trust that private information in your Apple iPhone will stay private.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Liquor stores prepare for battle as New York revisits to-go drinks from the early pandemic days.
description: ALBANY, N.Y. — Amid the gloom and economic devastation that the pandemic first brought to New York, state officials introduced a crowd-pleasing salve: the temporary legalization of to-go alcoholic drinks.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Amid the gloom and economic devastation that the pandemic first brought to New York, state officials introduced a crowd-pleasing salve: the temporary legalization of to-go alcoholic drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s Grip on G.O.P. Faces New Strains
description: Shifts in polls of Republicans, disagreements on endorsements and jeers over vaccines hint at daylight between the former president and the right-wing movement he spawned.
content: About halfway into his Texas rally on Saturday evening, Donald J. Trump pivoted toward the teleprompter and away from a meandering set of grievances to rattle off a tightly prepared list of President Biden’s failings and his own achievements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Women under financial stress are more likely to be abused during the pandemic, researchers find.
description: Women who experienced financial hardship as a result of the pandemic were also more likely to be abused by their partners, according to an Australian study.
content: Not only has a “shadow” wave of violence against women emerged during the coronavirus pandemic, but women who experienced financial hardship as a result of the pandemic were also more likely to be abused by their partners, according to a study released on Monday by Australian researchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: #MeToo Scandal at a Dutch TV Show Spurs a Sexual Assault Reckoning
description: The allegations against four men appearing on the Dutch version of “The Voice” talent show have helped to prompt a surge in reports of sexual assaults, victims’ groups say.
content: The Netherlands has long been considered open and liberated when it comes to sexuality. Sex work is legal, and nudity and sex scenes on television and in movies barely raise an eyebrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: The Bengals and the Rams Bring Offensive Power to Super Bowl
description: The Super Bowl, set for Feb. 13 near Los Angeles, will feature two quarterbacks who were No. 1 draft picks: Cincinnati’s Joe Burrow and Matthew Stafford of the Rams.
content: After a string of five Super Bowls featuring either Tom Brady or Patrick Mahomes, Cincinnati’s Joe Burrow and the Rams’ Matthew Stafford, made sure that trend didn’t continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: The White House threatens sanctions against Putin’s ‘inner circle’ if Russia invades Ukraine.
description: The Biden administration said the penalties would exceed any levied recently against Russia. It is unclear whether the list of targets includes Vladimir V. Putin himself.
content: The White House said on Monday that it had developed “specific sanctions packages” to strike at Russian “elites” who are “in or near the inner circle of the Kremlin” should President Vladimir V. Putin order an invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Federal Judge Rejects Hate Crime Plea Deals in Ahmaud Arbery Killing
description: The victim’s mother had denounced the deals made with two of the men convicted of murder, saying she did not want them transferred to federal custody instead of state prison.
content: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Monday rejected plea agreements with the Justice Department for two of the three white men facing hate crime charges in the killing of Ahmaud Arbery after his family expressed fierce opposition to the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: ‘Everyone’s Looking for Plastic.’ As Waste Rises, So Does Recycling.
description: Plagued by plastic pollution, Senegal wants to replace pickers at the garbage dump with a formal recycling system that takes advantage of the new market for plastics.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — A crowd of people holding curved metal spikes jumped on trash spilling out of a dump truck in Senegal’s biggest landfill, hacking at the garbage to find valuable plastic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Home Team’ Review: Fumblecore
description: Kevin James plays the complicated N.F.L. coach Sean Payton in an uncomplicated Netflix family flick.
content: Last week, the N.F.L. head coach Sean Payton — the most successful coach in the New Orleans Saints’ franchise history — both announced his retirement and, for the extra point, had a cameo in a slapstick family flick about the time when the league suspended Payton for his role in a bounty program that gave cash bonuses to players who made opponents leave the field on a stretcher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: The Texas Oil Heir Who Took On Math’s Impossible Dare
description: James M. Vaughn Jr., wielding a fortune, argues that he brought about the Fermat breakthrough after the best and brightest had failed for centuries to solve the puzzle.
content: Fermat’s last theorem, a riddle put forward by one of history’s great mathematicians, had baffled experts for more than 300 years. Then a genius toiled in secret for seven years to solve it, according to the usual narrative. That shy Englishman, Andrew Wiles, made his feat public in the early 1990s and amassed a glittering array of tributes. In 2016, he won the Abel Prize, math’s top award. It came with a $700,000 purse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: On Star-Filled Nets, Rookies Not Serving as Just Understudies
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 31, 2022.
content: “At training camp, that was my first time being with the guys and all that. I’m seeing how they’re hooping and stuff, thinking ‘I’m probably not even touching the court this year.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac
title: How Facebook Is Morphing Into Meta
description: Shifting a 68,000-person social networking company toward the theoretical metaverse has caused internal disruption and uncertainty.
content: The Instagram engineer had already packed his bags for a December vacation when his boss pulled him into a virtual meeting to talk about job goals for 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Easy Covid entry rules help drive tourism to the Dominican Republic.
description: Some had come for the beach, some had come for the sun, others had picked it because, at the time, the Covid numbers seemed reasonable. Many had chosen it over resort destinations because getting there seemed easy. Still others liked the idea of not having to take a test to enter the country.
content: Some had come for the beach, some had come for the sun, others had picked it because, at the time, the Covid numbers seemed reasonable. Many had chosen it over resort destinations because getting there seemed easy. Still others liked the idea of not having to take a test to enter the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Matthew Futterman
title: Disgraced Running Coach Was Barred for Life for Alleged Sexual Assault
description: An arbitrator’s ruling, revealed for the first time, shows that allegations of physical assault prompted a lifetime ban for Alberto Salazar, the former coach of the Nike Oregon Project.
content: The famed running coach Alberto Salazar, who helped top Americans be more competitive in track and field before he was suspended for doping violations, was barred from the sport for life last month after an arbitrator found that he more likely than not had sexually assaulted an athlete on two different occasions, according to a summary of the ruling reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Indicted Trump Ally Says Prosecutors Stalled Case Until After Election
description: Thomas J. Barrack Jr., who is charged with illegally lobbying then-President Donald J. Trump, suggested that the delay in his prosecution was politically motivated.
content: Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a real-estate investor and close friend of former President Donald J. Trump, asked a federal judge to dismiss the foreign lobbying and obstruction of justice charges against him on Monday, contending that the Justice Department delayed prosecuting him until after Mr. Trump left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Uffizi Gallery, Bastion of Tradition, Evolves (Slowly) With the Times
description: Eike Schmidt, the director, says it is “very important to get the dust off and to show what is relevant.” The museum has been working toward that end.
content: FLORENCE, Italy — Walking past the Botticellis, Raphaels and Michelangelos at the Uffizi Gallery, one could understandably be surprised to come upon self-portraits by the Ethiopian artist Tesfaye Urgessa and the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How to Build Resilience in Hard Times
description: In “The Myth of Closure,” Pauline Boss offers guidance for moving forward amid the painful losses of the moment.
content: Many people I know are waiting, patiently or otherwise, for life to return to normal. We are eager for the day when we can again live without fear of a deadly virus that lurks like a stalker, disrupting social and cultural events, travel, education and life’s milestones that once missed, can never be retrieved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Krupke, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Kaitlin Roberts, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Lisa Tobin, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: We Need to Talk About Covid, Part 2: A Conversation with Dr. Fauci
description: Is it time to start thinking about the pandemic in a new way? We ask America’s top infectious disease expert.
content: America feels as if it might be at a turning point in how we think about and respond to the pandemic. There is universal vaccine access and we’re facing a variant — Omicron — that is meaningfully milder than its predecessors. The costs of our current approach in areas like children’s education and mental health are becoming high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Howard Hesseman, 81, the D.J. Johnny Fever in ‘WKRP in Cincinnati,’ Dies
description: Mr. Hesseman played a fallen radio star who landed in the Midwest on the popular sitcom, which captured the misadventures of a struggling station.
content: Howard Hesseman, the actor and improvisational comedian best known for playing a stuck-in-the-’60s radio disc jockey in the TV sitcom “WKRP in Cincinnati,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Aurelien Breeden
title: Putin and Macron talk again by phone, keeping diplomatic lines open.
description: The two leaders discussed Ukraine and Russia’s demand for “security guarantees” that would include a legally binding halt on NATO expansion to the east.
content: The diplomatic push to avert a wider conflict between Russia and Ukraine continued with President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking to the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, by telephone on Monday for the second time in four days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: February Vocabulary Challenge: Invent a Word
description: Come up with your own addition to the English language. Suggest a new word by Feb. 28, and it could become our April Fools’ Word of the Day.
content: “Of all the factors that transform how we communicate, none are so powerful as young people, who have always steered language,” writes book critic Parul Sehgal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 2 Recap: No One Is Safe
description: Prince and Chuck make the world a better place, each in his own underhanded way.
content: If you’re looking for the future of “Billions,” two quotes from this week’s episode point the way forward, I think. The first comes from Wendy Rhoades, describing to Taylor Mason her fear that their boss, Mike Prince, might suffer from narcissistic personality disorder: “He thinks he’s better than everyone else, and he won’t stop till he gets what he wants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Fever? Sore Throat? They Just Check ‘No’
description: Attestation forms for Covid may be turning us into fibbers.
content: Every morning, Ashley, a mother of two on Long Island, has to navigate an ethical minefield: Her children’s schools send out a health questionnaire for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Hargus Robbins, Pianist on Country Music Hits, Dies at 84
description: A revered member of Nashville’s A-Team of studio musicians, he was a major contributor to Bob Dylan’s “Blonde on Blonde” album.
content: NASHVILLE — Hargus “Pig” Robbins, one of country music’s most prolific session piano players and a key contributor to Bob Dylan’s landmark 1966 album, “Blonde on Blonde,” died on Sunday in Franklin, Tenn. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Ed Shanahan
title: Plea in Murder-for-Hire Plot Revives Questions About 2 Unsolved Deaths
description: The son of a New Jersey couple found dead in 2014 cites “eerily similar” circumstances in new revelations about a killing that year.
content: At dawn on Sept. 28, 2014, John Sheridan and his wife, Joyce, were found dead in their home north of Princeton, N.J. They had been stabbed, and a gasoline-fueled fire had been set in the bedroom near their bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Prosecutor Investigating Trump Seeks Safety Assistance From the F.B.I.
description: The Fulton County district attorney expressed concern about the former president’s comments at a rally in Texas.
content: ATLANTA — The district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., who is conducting a criminal investigation of former President Donald J. Trump has asked for an F.B.I. risk assessment of the county courthouse in downtown Atlanta, citing “alarming” rhetoric used by Mr. Trump at a rally in Texas over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Bhaskar and Alan Blinder
title: How This Small Town Keeps Its Olympic Shine
description: In Lake Placid, N.Y., nostalgia is a link to the region’s Olympic past.
content: Nestled in the Adirondacks, and deep in the American sports psyche, Lake Placid, N.Y., looks much as it did more than 40 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: To-Go Drinks Had Plenty of Fans in New York. Just Not the Right Ones.
description: Lawmakers are considering whether to permanently legalize to-go drinks, setting off a clash between liquor stores and restaurants.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Amid the gloom and economic devastation that the pandemic first brought to New York, state officials introduced a crowd-pleasing salve: the temporary legalization of to-go alcoholic drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shirley Ngozi Nwangwa
title: Multilayered Paintings That Pay Tribute to Hip-Hop Dances
description: In his latest works, the artist Troy Lamarr Chew II has embedded references to the Bart Simpson, the Shopping Cart and many other familiar moves.
content: Last year, Troy Lamarr Chew II spent countless hours in the studio. If he weren’t an artist, though, he might be a linguist, a semiotics professor or a rapper. Or at least that’s the sense you get after spending time with his “Slanguage” paintings, which are imbued with messages that aren’t immediately apparent, and that often require knowledge of wordplay to decode. The series began, in 2019, as a shout-out to regional slang from Oakland, Calif., and the rest of the Bay Area. Take “Yay Area” (2020), a realist composition that brings together recognizable and mundane food items: a Coca-Cola bottle turned on its side, a chocolate layer cake atop a pedestal and a glass bowl filled with scoops of vanilla ice cream. At first glance, the still life, which recalls the work of the American painter Wayne Thiebaud, impresses with its skill and precision and evokes nostalgia for sugary childhood treats. Depending on your familiarity with certain hip-hop lyrics, though, it may later occur to you that the artist has depicted foods whose names, like the “Yay” of the title, are slang for cocaine (coke, cola, cake), and one that references the Oakland artist Dru Down’s 1993 song “Ice Cream Man,” its title an allusion to a drug dealer (though he’s hardly the only rapper to have used the term). Another work of Chew’s, “Ball Street Journal” (2020), includes images of cheese, bread and paper — all terms for money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The New York Times Buys Wordle
description: The word game, released in October, has millions of daily users.
content: The sudden hit Wordle, in which once a day players get six chances to guess a five-letter word, has been acquired by The New York Times Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Lauren Hirsch
title: How Businesses in Texas and Florida Wrestle With States’ Vaccine Backlash
description: With the Biden administration’s attempt to impose a national standard blocked, companies must navigate a thicket of local rules as they try to return employees to the workplace.
content: The Biden administration’s attempt to impose a sweeping vaccine rule for private employers last year was met with a wave of state laws limiting company vaccine mandates. Texas and Florida were on the vanguard of that backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Power of Boosters
description: New C.D.C. data shows their effectiveness.
content: The C.D.C. has begun to publish data on Covid outcomes among people who have received booster shots, and the numbers are striking:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Steven Lee Myers and John Liu
title: Ahead of Winter Olympics, Beijing Moves to Quash Dissent
description: As athletes begin to arrive in China for the Olympics, the authorities are rounding up activists and shutting down social media accounts.
content: Chinese authorities have detained activists in their homes and sent others to jail. Censors have shut down the social media accounts of prominent critics. Officials have warned Olympians that protest could bring prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Artists and the Food That Inspires Them
description: ‘The Ucross Cookbook’ provides recipes and testimonials from an artist residency program founded in 1983.
content: Ucross, located on a ranch in northeast Wyoming, houses an artist residency program founded in 1983 and has provided inspiration to such figures as the poet and performer Karma Mayet Johnson, the journalist and novelist Suki Kim and the baritone Nathan Gunn, among many others. Their tenures at the ranch were punctuated by meals from the kitchen of Cindy Brooks, who, with Cree LeFavour, a former resident, has now written “The Ucross Cookbook.” (Sales support the nonprofit.) Worth preparing are caramelized carrots with ras-el-hanout; hard winter spinach soup; soba noodles with coconut, chiles and kale; and Powder River meatballs. “Poet’s Lunch” peanut butter cookies were a big hit, and I was delighted to see that someone beside me simmers jasmine rice in jasmine tea. The recipes do not provide yields, though the authors say one should assume around six servings for many. Experienced cooks would not be daunted. Testimonials by former residents and alluring landscape photos season the book’s pages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Report on Downing Street Parties Deepens Crisis for Boris Johnson
description: A long-awaited assessment on whether Downing Street flouted lockdown rules declared that there were “failures of leadership and judgment’’ by Mr. Johnson’s government.
content: LONDON — A long-awaited report on parties in Downing Street during the pandemic dealt Prime Minister Boris Johnson a stinging blow on Monday, condemning him for failed leadership and painting a damning picture of “excessive” workplace drinking in the inner sanctum of the British government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: In a New Documentary, Janet Jackson Is Hiding in Plain Sight
description: A four-hour film on Lifetime and A&E touches on the highs and lows of a long career, but doesn’t dig deep into one of pop’s great risk-takers.
content: Throughout her two-decade-plus heyday, Janet Jackson was an astonishingly modern pop superstar — a risk-taker with a distinctive voice, a vivid sense of self-presentation and an innate understanding of the scale of the labor required to make world-shaking music. She was the embodiment of authority and command, practically unrivaled in her day and studiously copied by later generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Breaking Bread’ Showcases the A-Sham Food Festival in Israel
description: The festival was created by Dr. Nof Atamna Ismaeel, in an effort to create bridges between communities.
content: In Haifa, Israel, the annual A-Sham Festival pairs Arab and Jewish chefs who showcase their traditional foods and foster understanding in the kitchen. It was created by Dr. Nof Atamna Ismaeel, a microbiologist and a winner of a popular Israeli reality chef show who identifies as Arab, Israeli and Palestinian. With “Breaking Bread,” the documentary filmmaker Beth Elise Hawk captured the festival in 2017 and 2018 with appropriately mouthwatering scenes. The emphasis of the film shows how chefs from different backgrounds, religions and cultures can cooperate. “When I founded the A-Sham festival I did not want to say Israel, I didn’t want to say Palestine,” Dr. Ismaeel said in the trailer for the documentary. “I don’t believe there is any room for politics in the kitchen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: The Sudden Rise of Wordle
description: Wordle, a popular word game, was purchased by The New York Times on Monday.
content: In less than six months, Wordle has gone from a gift to a viral sensation, to being an official part of The New York Times portfolio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: ‘I Have No Idea What You Just Said’: Concert Drowns Out A.F.C. Halftime Analysis
description: As the “NFL on CBS” crew broke down the first half of the game, a performance by the country music singer Walker Hayes was so loud, it made the commentary all but inaudible.
content: At halftime of the A.F.C. championship game on Sunday, Kansas City led the Cincinnati Bengals, 21-10. For the Bengals to win, they would need to make some adjustments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Covid’s New Divide: Risk Takers vs. the Risk Averse
description: In Italy, with its high vaccination rate, the social schism revolves less around who’s gotten a shot, and more around lifestyles and comfort levels of living with the coronavirus.
content: ROME — The entire family is vaccinated, even the relatives, and all abide by masking requirements and respect Italy’s tough coronavirus restrictions. They are also all over the place in how they are living their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How the Fed Is and Isn’t ‘the Supreme Court of Finance’
description: Both institutions are in the news. Let’s look at their similarities and differences.
content: The Federal Reserve is sometimes called “the Supreme Court of finance.” That’s a stretch, of course, but the analogy does make you think about the nature of both institutions. Now that they’re both in the news it seems like an opportune time to look at their similarities and differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials Make It Clear: This Time Is Different
description: Central bankers on Monday emphasized that conditions are better than they were the last time they backed off their efforts to prop up the U.S. economy.
content: Federal Reserve officials are preparing to pull back their economic help as inflation remains stubbornly high and the labor market swiftly heals, and they are signaling clearly that the last business cycle is a poor template for what comes next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration to Reinstate Mercury Pollution Rules Weakened Under Trump
description: The E.P.A. will resume enforcing limits on the release of mercury, a neurotoxin linked to developmental damage in children, from coal-burning power plants.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday reinstated a way of measuring the benefits of reducing air pollution, the first step in a plan that could tighten limits on the amount of mercury that can be discharged from coal-burning power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Diplomatic Clash Over Ukraine
description: Russians said the U.S. was fanning flames.
content: The United States and Russia engaged in a public diplomatic brawl Monday at the U.N. Security Council over the Ukraine crisis. Follow our live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Takamine, a Koji-Fermented Whiskey, Arrives Stateside
description: The spirit is named after Jokiche Takamine, a 19th century chemist who had a distillery in Chicago.
content: Koji, a type of mold, has been used in Japan for centuries in the fermentation needed to produce soy sauce, miso and sake. It can also be used to ferment grain for whiskey, which is usually made with malted barley. Takamine, an exceptionally smooth koji-fermented whiskey from Shinozaki Brewery & Distillery in Japan, is now available in the United States. It has a slight mushroom aroma and deserves to be sipped neat. You could call its arrival a return: In the 1890s, Jōkichi Takamine, a Japanese chemist who married an American woman, settled in Chicago and started producing koji-fermented whiskey. After the distillery was destroyed by a fire, he turned to medical research in New York and went on to isolate chemical adrenaline. His success allowed him to donate cherry trees to Washington, D.C., and to establish the Nippon Club in New York. He played a diplomatic role after World War I and is buried in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. The 8-year-old whiskey is the first product to bear his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: The maker of Hubble contact lenses will pay $3.5 million in F.T.C. settlement.
description: Industry professionals told The Times in 2019 that Hubble switched people out of their prescribed lens brands and into Hubble’s lenses, which could be harmful to customers.
content: Vision Path, the maker of Hubble contact lenses, will pay $3.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company failed to obtain customers’ prescriptions or to properly verify prescription information and that it substituted Hubble lenses for those actually prescribed to consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.9 Million Homes in California
description: A Mission Revival house in San Francisco, a mountain estate in Ojai and a 1918 bungalow in San Jose.
content: With its quiet, tree-lined streets and single-family homes just 20 minutes from downtown San Francisco, the Balboa Terrace neighborhood is popular with those who want to live in the city but enjoy the comforts of the suburbs. Aptos Park, a green space with a children’s playground and tennis courts, is a five-minute walk, and a light rail station is just half a mile away, at Ocean Avenue and Junipero Serra Boulevard. Stonestown Galleria, a shopping center with a Target, a Trader Joe’s and a movie theater, is a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Two Police Officers Suspended Over Handling of Black Women’s Deaths
description: The mayor said the officers had shown a “lack of sensitivity” in dealing with the cases of Lauren Smith-Fields and Brenda Lee Rawls, who died in Bridgeport, Conn., on the same day.
content: They heard from a neighbor that their sister, Brenda Lee Rawls, had died. But they couldn’t find her body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Does Spotify Have an Identity Crisis?
description: In response to criticism of Joe Rogan’s podcast, the streaming service says it’s a platform, not a media company. That’s a familiar refrain.
content: Spotify has faced increasing pressure as high-profile artists have pulled their songs from the streaming platform to protest its hosting of Joe Rogan’s popular podcast, which has been criticized for spreading misinformation about the coronavirus. Over the weekend, Spotify’s C.E.O., Daniel Ek, said that the service would add a “content advisory” to some podcasts and Rogan pledged to “balance things out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Former Miss USA Cheslie Kryst Dies at 30
description: Ms. Kryst, who was also a correspondent for the television show “Extra,” was found dead on Sunday in New York.
content: Cheslie Kryst, a correspondent for the celebrity news program “Extra” who won the Miss USA title in 2019 while working as a lawyer, was found dead on Sunday in New York. She was 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: An Omicron surge across Asia restricts travel during the Lunar New Year weekend.
description: The Omicron variant has dampened the plans of tens of millions of people across several Asian countries to travel for the holiday.
content: The Omicron variant has dampened the plans of tens of millions of people across several Asian countries to travel during the Lunar New Year, as officials battle the pandemic for a third year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Nothing’s More Fun Than Picking the Next Supreme Court Justice. Right?
description: Sometimes fulfilling a campaign promise gets tricky.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, President Biden has announced that he will nominate a Black woman to replace Justice Stephen Breyer. Is this a good idea, politically speaking?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Path to Social Equity in Higher Ed Doesn’t Run Through Harvard
description: We need a broader vision of equity.
content: Last Thursday, I wrote about the Harvard affirmative action case and what I see as a broken system of racial preferences at elite colleges. Today, I want to broaden the scope a bit and talk about higher education in general and what life might be like after the Supreme Court ultimately decides the fate of affirmative action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why This Democratic Governor Seems to Be Over Covid
description: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado defends his relatively laissez-faire approach to pandemic response.
content: As Omicron surged across the country, Democratic and Republican governors alike doubled down on indoor mask mandates and declared states of emergency. But when asked whether he would make masks mandatory, Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado declared, “The emergency is over.” Unlike Ron DeSantis of Florida, Greg Abbott of Texas and other governors who have refused mandates, Polis is a lifelong Democrat. His take: Omicron is “a very different situation than early 2020” and there’s a “silent majority” who are already vaccinated and want to choose how they manage their risk. Or, as he put it in an interview, “At this point, if you haven’t been vaccinated, it’s really your own darn fault.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Repeats at No. 1 for a Third Time
description: The Disney album held off the latest from the prolific rapper YoungBoy Never Broke Again on the Billboard 200.
content: The soundtrack to “Encanto,” Disney’s latest animated hit, tops the Billboard album chart for a third time this week, holding off the latest from the popular and prolific rapper YoungBoy Never Broke Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John M. Barry
title: What We Can Learn From How the 1918 Pandemic Ended
description: Overconfidence, indifference and weariness are perhaps the biggest dangers.
content: Most histories of the 1918 influenza pandemic that killed at least 50 million people worldwide say it ended in the summer of 1919 when a third wave of the respiratory contagion finally subsided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: An Electrifying View of the Heart of the Milky Way
description: A new radio-wave image of the center of our galaxy reveals all the forms of frenzy that a hundred million or so stars can get up to.
content: Noise and chaos reign at the heart of the Milky Way, our home galaxy, or so it appears in an astonishing image captured recently by astronomers in South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: 50 Queens Chefs Share Their Favorite Things
description: Queens Chef Project, a digital presentation, will explore objects that are important to chefs like Anastasia Tjahjadi of Warung Selasa.
content: The diversity of cuisines that make up the mosaic that is Queens is explored in an online exhibition through objects that are important to 50 chefs. Among those who tell their stories are Chintan Pandya of Adda with his skewers, and Anastasia Tjahjadi (known as Dewi) of Warung Selasa with a volcanic stone mortar and pestle. Drew Kerr, a communications consultant from Queens, created the project, shot the photographs and interviewed the chefs with the help of Joe DiStefano, a Queens-based food writer and publicist, and Jonathan Forgash, a founder of Queens Together, a nonprofit that supports restaurants in the borough. They received no compensation for their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Missing in Brooks County’ and ‘Sisters With Transistors’
description: A documentary about a Texas border region plays as part of PBS’s “Independent Lens” series. And a documentary about women in electronic music airs on Showtime.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 21-Feb. 6. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Learning With the ‘Black History, Continued’ Series
description: In this extended lesson plan, students will use this special Times series to deepen, expand and challenge their understanding of Black life, culture and history in America.
content: Featured Series: “Black History, Continued”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Last Sex-Crime Inquiry Into Andrew Cuomo Is Dropped
description: There was insufficient evidence to charge Mr. Cuomo, the former governor of New York, with a crime in Oswego County, the prosecutor announced on Monday.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The last of five criminal investigations into allegations of sexual misconduct against former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo ended on Monday with the Oswego County district attorney joining his peers in concluding that there were insufficient legal grounds to bring criminal charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: With Breyer’s Exit, a Farewell to Marshmallow Guns and Tomato Children
description: Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who said last week that he planned to retire, enlivened Supreme Court arguments with questions that could confuse and amuse.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Stephen G. Breyer has a mild temperament, and he writes cautious opinions. But his questions from the bench can be wild flights of fancy, enlivening the proceedings with musings about marshmallow guns, aspirin fingers, tomato children and the Pussycat Burglar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Rachel Maddow, MSNBC’s No. 1 star, is taking a hiatus.
description: The anchor is expected to be off until April, leaving MSNBC with a hole in the coveted 9 p.m. weeknight time slot.
content: Rachel Maddow, the top-rated anchor on MSNBC and one of the most influential figures in liberal media, is set to take a hiatus from her nightly cable program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California’s Single-Payer Health Care Proposal Faces Crucial Vote
description: The bill must pass the State Assembly on Monday to survive.
content: For years, the single-payer health care movement has found traction in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: What a Disconnect From Swift Would Mean for Russia
description: A Belgian financial messaging service is once again at the center of an international sanctions fight.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has pledged that if Russia invades Ukraine it will face “severe economic consequences,” with the United States likely to unleash a blistering package of sanctions that would effectively cut the Russian economy off from much of the global financial system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Up Next for Rafael Nadal? His Specialty, the French Open.
description: Nadal could strike quickly for Grand Slam singles title No. 22, particularly if Novak Djokovic, the only man to beat him twice in Paris, is unable to play because he remains unvaccinated.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — After Rafael Nadal’s stupendous comeback in the Australian Open final on Sunday night, it is he — not Novak Djokovic or Roger Federer — who is the first man to win 21 Grand Slam singles titles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeline Tolle
title: Documenting Los Angeles’s Unlikely Urban Fishermen
description: The act of fishing in Los Angeles seems almost defiant: a tranquil outdoors activity against a backdrop of concrete, litter and highway overpasses.
content: It’s hard to imagine there was ever a time when the Los Angeles River was wild and free flowing, flanked by thick reed forests and full of steelhead trout — instead of clad in concrete and sandwiched between swollen expressways and freight-train tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Designates Qatar as a Major Non-NATO Ally
description: The move clears the way for greater security cooperation and investment at a time when President Biden is seeking help boosting natural gas supplies in Europe.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday named Qatar as a “major non-NATO ally” of the United States, a designation that clears the way for greater security cooperation and investment in the Gulf nation at a time when Mr. Biden is seeking help boosting natural gas supplies in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: N.Y.C.’s Lopsided Recovery
description: The city’s rebound has been slow, and unequal.
content: In New York City, the Omicron wave is making the city’s already lopsided recovery even more so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Mr. Trudeau, who has been isolating since Thursday after a coronavirus exposure, confirmed his positive test result on Monday morning.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has tested positive for the coronavirus after an exposure last week. He said on Twitter that he was not feeling ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Savor, Celebrate and Pay Attention: 8 Lessons From the Eat Well Challenge
description: It’s not always easy to change your eating habits, but mindfulness can help you improve the quality of your daily diet, without food restrictions.
content: As a chronic dieter for most of my life, it hasn’t been easy to kick the dieting habit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Britain’s health secretary calls for a review of a vaccine mandate for health care workers in England.
description: A deadline of April 1, imposed in the fall when Delta was raging, may not be the right policy for Omicron, the health secretary, Sajid Javid, said on Monday.
content: Frontline health workers in England may no longer be required to get vaccinated, Britain’s health secretary said on Monday. He recommended a review of a mandate that employers and trade unions have warned would lead to crippling staff shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: For Some of Ukraine’s Neighbors, ‘Defend Europe’ Has Another Meaning
description: For the populist leaders of Poland and Hungary, Russia’s saber-rattling on the border with Ukraine takes a back seat to domestic politics and issues like immigration.
content: WARSAW — As the United States ramped up warnings of a Russian attack, and as Western allies called for unity against aggression, the leaders of two NATO members bordering Ukraine headed for a gathering in Madrid over the weekend called “Defend Europe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleni Courea
title: The Next Few Days Are Critical for Boris Johnson
description: Is this the end for the prime minister?
content: LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s classics-loving prime minister, has long been fascinated by the fall of the Roman Empire. Now his government risks a fall of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Republicans ‘Have Chosen to Wreck the Nashville District’
description: Representative Jim Cooper won re-election again and again because he is a good politician and a good man. But he finally lost to Republican gerrymandering.
content: NASHVILLE — When Representative Jim Cooper announced last week that he would be retiring after 32 years in Congress, the 67-year-old did not mince words about his reasons for stepping down: “I could not stop the General Assembly from dismembering Nashville. No one tried harder to keep our city whole.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Rising Human Cost of Sports Betting
description: The ends of the college and pro football seasons were already a perilous time for people recovering from a gambling addiction. Then came the onslaught of ads for legal sports betting.
content: We’re heading toward the Super Bowl, a time of joy and anticipation for most sports fans. But not for all. Certainly not for Steven Delaney. He has no plans to watch the big game. Watching sports of any kind could suck him back in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Migrant Worker’s Tale of Inequality Grips China, Then Is Erased
description: A man with Covid revealed a parallel universe to well-off Chinese and became a symbol of inequality. The government found him inconvenient to its narrative.
content: He visited 28 places in the first 18 days of 2022, including a puppet theater, a few luxury residential compounds and a shopping mall in the heart of China’s equivalent of Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hayley Phelan
title: ‘Jeuje,’ ‘Zhoosh,’ ‘Zhuzh’: A Word of Many Spellings, and Meanings
description: Commonly used to describe that extra something added to almost anything, the slang term has a centuries-long history.
content: When you fluff up pillows on your well-worn sofa, or turn your shirt sleeves up just-so, or sprinkle some spices over your morning eggs, you may be engaging in the art of the “jeuje.” Or is it “zhoosh”? Make that “zhuzh.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 31, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 31, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rush for a Slice of Paradise in Puerto Rico
description: Many Puerto Ricans say they can no longer afford to remain in their homes with outside investors buying up properties and driving up prices.
content: RINCÓN, P.R. — The last time strangers approached Samuel Sánchez Tirado while he was trimming his front lawn, he pretended to be the landscaper so that they would leave him alone. He knew what the uninvited visitors wanted, and he was tired of having the same conversation over and over again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: An Opera Sings of a World on the Verge of Ending
description: Ricky Ian Gordon’s “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” is set in a community of Italian Jews just before World War II.
content: One of the many things that came to an end in the conflagration of World War II was the great Italian opera tradition. Puccini, its apotheosis, had died in 1924; in the conflict’s wake, modernism ruled European music, and a certain strand of lyric theater was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Meaning of Spam, Onstage
description: A multimedia performance, “Specially Processed American Me ,” will show at Dixon Place on the Lower East Side.
content: Spam, the tinned pork product created by Hormel Foods 85 years ago, is a longstanding subject of delight to some and derision to others. It was a mainstay in the American military and became popular in Asian and Pacific communities, first near U.S. bases, notably in Hawaii and Korea, before becoming widespread. Now, a staged multimedia exploration of the meaning of Spam, written by the playwright and artist Jaime Sunwoo for whom Spam tugs emotional strings, is being performed in a collaboration with her company, Free Rein Projects, Ping Chong and Company, and the Dixon Place theater on the Lower East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: Video of Mentally Ill Woman Chained in Shack Stirs Anger in China
description: Public discussion of mental illness has grown in recent years, but in rural areas, resources and acceptance are still limited.
content: The video was seemingly everywhere on the Chinese internet: A middle-aged woman standing in a doorless brick shack, a dazed expression on her face, wearing no coat though it was the middle of winter. Around her neck was a metal chain, shackling her to the wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Proposed sanctions against Russia.
content: During the coronavirus pandemic, China has honed its powers to track and corral its 1.4 billion citizens, backed by upgraded technology, armies of neighborhood workers and broad public support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Garcia
title: In Isabel Allende’s New Novel, One Hundred Years of Attitude
description: A centenarian’s life mirrors the turbulence of her country’s in “Violeta.”
content: VIOLETABy Isabel AllendeTranslated by Frances Riddle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: The Joe Rogan debate poses an existential question for Spotify.
description: The streaming service says it is not responsible for moderating content on its platform, but many believe it should act more like a media company because it pays for that content.
content: Spotify has faced increasing pressure as prominent artists have pulled their songs from the streaming platform to protest its hosting of Joe Rogan’s popular podcast, which has been criticized for spreading misinformation about the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
title: Justin Trudeau Condemns Convoy Protesting Pandemic Restrictions
description: The Canadian prime minister, who tested positive for Covid-19, railed against protesters for violence, racism and spreading misinformation.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on Monday lashed out at protests against pandemic restrictions over the weekend in Ottawa, chastising demonstrators for desecrating war memorials, wielding Nazi symbols and stealing food from the homeless. The protest was a culmination of a group of Canadian truckers and their supporters who drove from Western Canada to Ottawa to challenge government vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Ephrat Livni
title: Two top New York public prosecutors rejoin private practice.
description: Audrey Strauss is returning to the law firm Fried Frank, and Cyrus Vance Jr. is starting a new job as a partner at the law firm Baker McKenzie.
content: Audrey Strauss and Cyrus R. Vance Jr., two prosecutors in New York whose offices have tangled with former President Donald J. Trump, are heading back to private legal practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: teem
description: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Chicken Reported to Be Doing Well After Successful Restaurant Transplant
description: Barbuto, Jonathan Waxman’s long-running West Village restaurant, has brought its charms to a new address, including that celebrated roast chicken.
content: When the chef Jonathan Waxman opened Barbuto in 2004, the bookies of the food scene put long odds on its survival. Since making Jams into one of the defining New York feeding grounds of the 1980s and then losing it and two other restaurants by the end of the decade, Mr. Waxman had become something of a drifting gunman for hire, moving from one consulting job to another. One veteran critic told me confidently, when I said this new place looked promising, “He’ll be gone in a year.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: When Life Changed, Reiki, Tarot and a Home Redo Were There to Help
description: Helen Ho was laid off from her urban planning job at the beginning of the pandemic. She saw it as a chance to focus on the things she really liked doing.
content: When Helen Ho was laid off from her urban planning job in the spring of 2020, she knew she wouldn’t be looking for another full-time job anytime soon. The pandemic was slowly consuming every bit of our public and private lives, and eradicating many job prospects for the unemployed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Wealth Inequality Drives the Appeal of Crypto
description: To digital natives, crypto as a path to financial security just sounds sensible.
content: While I was preparing this week’s newsletter about the cultural economics of cryptocurrency and blockchain, crypto trading tanked. Suddenly, my concerns about how different groups of people have different levels of exposure to risky financial instruments became even more urgent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Rihanna and the Art of the Pregnancy Portrait Shoot
description: With a series of photos, Rihanna and ASAP Rocky take a modern phenomenon to a new level.
content: The art form known as the “celebrity pregnancy photo shoot” has a new winning entry. Rihanna and ASAP Rocky have announced their first child with the release of a street shot by Miles Diggs, a.k.a., Diggzy, a.k.a., the 20-something photographer named by Vogue as “fashion’s favorite paparazzi.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks had a lousy start to the year, but Wall Street expects good times ahead.
description: Investors have been fretting about the Federal Reserve’s efforts to fight inflation by raising interest rates.
content: It once was a rule of thumb on Wall Street that January set the tone for the year. By that measure, the forecast for stocks in 2022 would be downbeat, and subject to wild swings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Albany Story: Drinks to Go, the Pandemic and Lobbyists
description: Takeout drinks were legalized early in the pandemic, but only temporarily. Lobbyists for liquor stores headed off a move to make them permanent.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at to-go drinks, which have powerful opponents in Albany. We’ll also meet a man with enough memories of the Waldorf Astoria to win a contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Will East Harlem Ever Get its Long-Delayed Subway?
description: Residents have been waiting almost a century for new stations. Some aren’t sure they’ll be built.
content: Politicians have long promised to bring East Harlem a new subway line that would give this historically neglected community better transit access to the rest of New York and shift passengers away from some of the country’s most crowded train lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Russia-Ukraine, Boris Johnson, Lunar New Year: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: A coronavirus infection illuminates a migrant worker’s tale of inequality in China.
description: He visited 28 places in the first 18 days of 2022, including a puppet theater, a few luxury residential compounds and a shopping mall in the heart of China’s equivalent of Silicon Valley.
content: He visited 28 places in the first 18 days of 2022, including a puppet theater, a few luxury residential compounds and a shopping mall in the heart of China’s equivalent of Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Nicholas Fandos
title: N.Y. Democrats Could Gain 3 House Seats Under Proposed District Lines
description: The state Republican chairman denounced a new map that would reconfigure congressional districts to benefit Democrats as “filthy, partisan gerrymandering.”
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York Democrats on Sunday proposed a starkly partisan redesign of the state’s congressional map that would be one of the most consequential in the nation, offering the party’s candidates an advantage in 22 of the state's 26 House districts in this fall’s midterm election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Power Law’ Is a Funder-Friendly Look at the World of Venture Capital
description: In his new book, Sebastian Mallaby mentions the “alleged shortcomings” of venture capital but is ultimately bullish about what it has to offer.
content: It might be hard for most Americans to muster much sympathy for ultrarich venture capitalists, but Sebastian Mallaby wants us to try. In his new book, “The Power Law,” he argues that the funders of troubled outfits like WeWork and Uber have been unfairly maligned as exceedingly greedy and insufficiently skeptical — all too willing to look the other way when the entrepreneurs they back do something stupid or reprehensible, as long as there’s oodles of money to be made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Private Data Shows Broadway’s Hits and Misses After Reopening
description: Big shows did well when they returned in the fall after the long pandemic shutdown but new plays struggled, previously undisclosed industry data shows.
content: During the long dark months when the coronavirus pandemic kept Broadway shuttered, a hypothesis took hold in parts of the industry: Once theaters reopened, the audience would include more New Yorkers and fewer tourists, and the result could be a more receptive marketplace for ambitious new plays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘I’m Not for Everybody’: Jimmy Butler on Evolving With the Miami Heat
description: As Butler leads the Heat to the No. 1 seed in the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference, he said he increasingly sees his role as allowing others to shine.
content: The N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference is up for grabs, and a well-caffeinated Jimmy Butler has the Miami Heat primed to secure a premier seeding down the season’s stretch run. Miami reconstructed its roster in the off-season, most notably through the addition of point guard Kyle Lowry, and has pushed through a rash of injuries, to players including Butler and Bam Adebayo, to sit atop the conference standings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Sony to buy game maker Bungie in $3.6 billion deal.
description: The deal follows two other major acquisitions in the game market by Microsoft and Take-Two Interactive.
content: Sony Interactive Entertainment said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the video game maker Bungie in a deal valued at $3.6 billion, as the game market further consolidates around some of its biggest companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Europe’s economy shows resilience to a surge in coronavirus infections.
description: The eurozone economy grew 0.3 percent in the last three months of 2021, despite a contraction in its traditional engine, Germany.
content: The eurozone’s economy proved its ability to withstand the Omicron variant of the coronavirus and persistent supply chain disruptions late last year, despite a split in the region that brought faster growth in France, Spain and Italy than in Europe’s traditional economic engine, Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naz Deravian
title: A Creamy-Crunchy Crowd-Pleasing Chicken Salad
description: A timeless dish, hot chicken salad has many iterations, but always brings joy.
content: A quintessential American casserole, hot chicken salad is timeless, a comfort food that never disappoints and comes together in no time. It takes the components of a classic chicken salad, tops it off with something salty and crisp, and bakes in the oven until warm, bubbly, creamy and crunchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In Kazakh Uprising, Reports of Widespread Abuses by Security Forces
description: Through crowdsourcing, rights groups say they are documenting a campaign of beatings and torture.
content: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — One evening in early January, Yerlan Zhagiparov left his home to see what was happening nearby at the city’s Republic Square, a center of mass political protests. Less than half an hour later, Mr. Zhagiparov, 49, called a close friend to say he had been apprehended by the National Guard. The phone cut out after his friend heard him screaming in pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fine Tinned Seafood From the Cervo’s and Hart’s Team
description: Canned cod livers, sardines and sockeye salmon are available from the new offshoot, Minnow.
content: Monkfish livers are rightly touted as the foie gras of the sea. Nialls Fallon, Leah Campbell and Nick Perkins, restaurateurs and lovers of fine tinned seafood, are importing a delectable alternative: cod livers from Iceland. Use the smooth, buttery pieces as a spread on toast, to top grilled fish or to fold into pasta sauce. But once you open the can, use it all; it doesn’t keep well. The livers are one of three seafood products sold by Minnow, a new offshoot of their restaurants Hart’s, Cervo’s and the Fly. Lovely little sardines from Spain and wild Bristol Bay sockeye salmon are also available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Novavax applies to the F.D.A. for authorization of its Covid vaccine.
description: The protein-based shot, already authorized in some parts of the world, has faced long delays, and it is not clear what role it will play in the United States.
content: The pharmaceutical company Novavax said on Monday that it had submitted an application to the Food and Drug Administration seeking authorization for its long-delayed protein-based coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Isabel Kershner
title: Cyprus Overturns Conviction of Woman Who Accused Israelis of Rape
description: More than two years after a British woman was convicted of fabricating claims, Cyprus’s top court reversed the decision and said that she had not received a fair trial.
content: The Supreme Court of Cyprus on Monday overturned the conviction of a British woman accused of fabricating claims that a group of Israeli tourists raped her in a hotel room in Cyprus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diante Lee
title: What We Learned From the N.F.L.’s Conference Championships
description: The Bengals’ defense had the antidote for Patrick Mahomes’s late-game magic, and the Rams did just enough to keep San Francisco’s offense in check.
content: The 2021-22 sports year is hellbent on healing wounded fan bases. The state of Georgia saw its Major League Baseball franchise and flagship college football program win titles, Milwaukee won its first N.B.A. championship since Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was tossing up sky hooks, and the Cincinnati Bengals are now Super Bowl-bound for the first time in 33 years, after a 24-21 overtime win in Kansas City, Mo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: At the ‘Logistics Games,’ Just Arriving Is a Victory
description: Wrestling P.C.R. tests, QR codes and a ticking clock, officials tasked with getting teams to Beijing say planning is the Olympics’ newest high-stakes event.
content: Burner phones and loaner laptops. Quarantine training centers and a bubble the size of a small city. Departure tests and arrival tests and daily tests. So. Many. Tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: For This Menu, Start With Dessert
description: A tangerine flan, prepared in advance, ends this midwinter menu of brightly dressed chicories and rich pork chops from David Tanis.
content: Dessert may cap a meal, but there’s wisdom in putting it first and foremost, particularly when preparing a large dinner. In fact, cooking dessert before anything else is often a wise strategy. The job is then out of the way, so you can concentrate on the savory dishes. And if you can make the dessert a full day ahead, so much the better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: John K. Singlaub, 100, General Who Clashed With Jimmy Carter, Dies
description: After a career in military intelligence, waging war in Europe, Korea and Vietnam, he was forced out of the U.S. Army. He then aided the contras in Nicaragua.
content: Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who waged clandestine warfare for the U.S. Army and the C.I.A. from the World War II years to Vietnam, then retired from the military under pressure after repeatedly criticizing President Jimmy Carter’s national security policies, died on Saturday. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
title: Teenage Inmates Found Among the 500 Dead in Syria Prison Attack
description: The bodies of at least two boys were found on a street behind the prison — the first confirmed deaths among up to 700 teenagers who had been detained there because they were the children of ISIS fighters.
content: HASAKA, Syria — The boy had dark brown hair coated in white dust, and on his chin were the wispy beginnings of a beard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Leader of Australian Megachurch Steps Down After Charge Over Father’s Sexual Abuse
description: Brian Houston, who was the leader of Hillsong, is accused of concealing past abuse by his father, who later died and was never charged.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The leader of Hillsong, the Australian megachurch that has attracted throngs of young people and celebrities worldwide, has stepped down as he prepares to fight a criminal charge of concealing historical child sexual abuse by his father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: Russia, Ukraine and ‘Hybrid Conflicts’
description: Four new books investigate modern warfare by examining limited conflicts by great powers.
content: While America retreats inward, several new studies from academic publishers read like news bulletins from small conflicts overseas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: How Much Have You Learned About Black History?
description: What have you learned about Black history at home or in school? In your opinion, have you received a robust and accurate education?
content: Black History Month has been celebrated in the United States for close to a hundred years. Leaders like Carter G. Woodson created the annual observance to ensure that the history of Black people in the United States received the importance and scholarly attention it deserves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Why the ‘Euphoria’ Teens Listen to Sinead O’Connor, Tupac and Selena
description: The hit HBO show’s maximalist, era-jumping soundtrack is unconcerned with realism, packing in dozens of songs, from the underground to the instantly recognizable.
content: A modern high schooler’s birthday party, chaperoned by an inebriated mother with no household rules except discretion, gets going to the sound of Montell Jordan’s “This Is How We Do It,” that indelible 1990s relic. “I love this song!” the mom squeals, with an added profanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Portugal’s Socialists Win an Outright Majority in Parliamentary Election
description: Because of a strong performance in the snap elections, the governing party will not have to form a coalition in the fractious Parliament.
content: LISBON — Portugal’s governing Socialist Party was victorious in snap elections on Sunday, winning enough seats in Parliament to govern without a coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. and Russian Diplomats Clash at U.N. Security Council Meeting
description: Russia called the public meeting on the Ukraine crisis an example of “megaphone diplomacy,” while the U.S. criticized Russia, saying, “Imagine how uncomfortable you would be if you had 100,000 troops sitting at your border.”

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Enjoy a taste of youthful nostalgia: chicken tenders. Or, turn them into meatballs.
content: Good morning. There is nothing wrong with a dinner of chicken tenders and fry sauce. This is particularly the case if there’s a child in the house, or a young adult who used to be a child, or anyone in need of pure comfort in advance of a screening of “Balto II” or the latest episode of “Euphoria.”
source.name: The New York Times
